problem_text:
The well-known Baer–Suzuki theorem states that if every two conjugates of an element a of a finite group G generate a finite p-subgroup, then a is contained in a normal p-subgroup.
a) Does such a theorem hold in the class of periodic groups? The case p = 2 is of particular interest.
b) Does such a theorem hold in the class of binary finite groups?
A. V. Borovik
answer:
a) No, it does not hold for p = 2 (V. D. Mazurov, A. Yu. Olshanskii, A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 54, no. 2 (2015), 161–166).
b) Yes, such a theorem does hold for binary finite groups. By the Baer–Suzuki theorem ⟨a1, b⟩is a finite p-group for any element a1 ∈aG = {ag | g ∈G} and for any p-element b ∈G. Now induction on n yields that the product a1 · · · an is a p-element for any a1, . . . , an ∈aG. (A. I. Sozutov, Siberian Math. J., 41, no. 3 (2000), 561–562.)
